sen.j: 万寿寺（まんじゅじ）は京都市東山区にある東福寺の塔頭である。
sen.e: Manju-ji Temple is a sub-temple located within the precinct of Tofuku-ji Temple in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Manju-ji Temple is a sub-temple located within the precinct of Tofuku-ji Temple in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
Manju-ji Temple is a sub-temple located within the precinct of Tofuku-ji Temple in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: かつては天龍寺・相国寺・建仁寺・東福寺とともに京都五山のひとつとして栄えた。
sen.e: It was once one of the Kyoto Gozan (five great Zen temples of Kyoto) along with Tenryu-ji Temple, Shokoku-ji Temple, Kennin-ji Temple and Tofuku-ji Temple.
It was once one of the Kyoto Gozan (five great Zen temples of Kyoto) along with Tenryu-ji Temple, Shokoku-ji Temple, Kennin-ji Temple and Tofuku-ji Temple.
It was once one of the Kyoto Gozan (five great Zen temples of Kyoto) along with Tenryu-ji Temple, Shokoku-ji Temple, Kennin-ji Temple and Tofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 非公開のため拝観はできない。
sen.e: It cannot be visited as it is not open to the general public.
It cannot be visited as it is not open to the general public.
It cannot be visited as it is not open to the general public.

sen.j: 万寿寺の起源は、平安時代後期、白河天皇が六条内裏に建てた六条御堂にさかのぼる。
sen.e: The origins of Manju-ji Temple date back to the Rokujo Mido (Buddhist statue hall) constructed at Rokujo Dairi (imperial palace) by Emperor Shirakawa in the latter part of the Heian period.
The origins of Manju-ji Temple date back to the Rokujo Mido (Buddhist statue hall) constructed at Rokujo Dairi (imperial palace) by Emperor Shirakawa in the latter part of the Heian period.
The origins of Manju-ji Temple date back to the Rokujo Mido (Buddhist statue hall) constructed at Rokujo Dairi (imperial palace) by the Emperor Shirakawa in the latter part of the Heian period.

sen.j: 『京城万寿禅寺記』などによると、白河天皇の皇女である郁芳門院（てい子内親王）が永長元年（1096年）に数え年21歳で亡くなり、それを悲しんだ天皇が皇女の菩提のために六条御堂を建てた。
sen.e: According to sources including "Keijo Manjuzenji-ki", the Rokujo Mido was built by the grieving Emperor Shirakawa in order to pray for the soul of his wife Yuhomonin (Imperial Princess Teiko) who died in 1096 aged 21.

According to sources including "Keijo Manjuzenji-ki", the Rokujo Mido was built by the grieving Emperor Shirakawa in order to pray for the soul of his wife Yuhomonin (Imperial Princess Teiko) who died in 1096 aged 21.

According to sources including "Keijo Manjuzenji-ki," the Rokujo Mido was built by the grieving Emperor Shirakawa in order to pray for the soul of his wife Yuhomonin (Imperial Princess Teiko) who died in 1096 aged 21.

sen.j: 天皇が出家して上皇となったのも皇女の死がきっかけであったという。
sen.e: It is also said that her death led to the emperor retiring to the Buddhist priesthood.
It is also said that her death led to the emperor retiring to the Buddhist priesthood.
It is also said that her death led to the emperor retiring to the Buddhist priesthood.

sen.j: この御堂は、鎌倉時代には法然の弟子・湛空（1176年-1253年）が住し、湛空から十地覚空に受け継がれた。
sen.e: Tanku (1176-1253), a disciple of Honen, resided at this mido during the Kamakura period before he passed it on to Jichi Kakuku.
Tanku (1176-1253), a disciple of Honen, resided at this mido during the Kamakura period before he passed it on to Jichi Kakuku.
Tanku (1176-1253), a disciple of Honen, resided at this mido during the Kamakura period before he passed it on to Jichi Kakuku.

sen.j: この頃には天台系浄土教の寺であったと見られる。
sen.e: It is known to have been a Tendai Pure Land Sect temple at this time.
It is known to have been a Tendai Pure Land Sect temple at this time.
It is known to have been a Tendai Pure Land Sect temple at this time.

sen.j: 正嘉年間（1257年-1259年）、十地覚空とその弟子の東山湛照が東福寺の円爾に帰依して臨済宗寺院となり、寺号も万寿禅寺と改めた。
sen.e: Between 1257 and 1259, Jichi Kakuku and his disciple Tozan Tansho became devoted to Enni of Tofuku-ji Temple, and the temple converted to the Rinzai Sect with the name being changed to Manju-ji Temple.

Between 1257 and 1259, Jichi Kakuku and his disciple Tozan Tansho became devoted to Enni of Tofuku-ji Temple, and the temple converted to the Rinzai Sect with the name being changed to Manju-ji Temple.

Between 1257 and 1259, Jichi Kakuku and his disciple Tozan Tansho became devoted to Enni of Tofuku-ji Temple, and the temple converted to the Rinzai Sect with the name being changed to Manju-ji Temple.

sen.j: 弘長元年（1261年）に開堂の儀が行われている。
sen.e: The opening ceremony was held in 1261.
The opening ceremony was held in 1261.
The opening ceremony was held in 1261.

sen.j: その後、文永10年（1273年）に火災に遭い、元徳2年（1330年）には後宇多天皇皇女の崇明門院から土地を賜って、六条の旧地のやや北方、高倉通の西、樋口小路（現代の万寿寺通）の南の地点に移転した。
sen.e: The temple was later damaged by fire in 1273 but granted land by Sumeimonin, the wife of Emperor Go-Uda, in 1330 and was relocated slightly north of the former Rokujo site to a location west of Takakura-dori Street and south of Higuchikoji (present-day Manjuji-dori Street).

The temple was later damaged by fire in 1273 but granted land by Sumeimonin, the wife of Emperor Go-Uda, in 1330 and was relocated slightly north of the former Rokujo site to a location west of Takakura-dori Street and south of Higuchikoji (present-day Manjuji-dori Street).

The temple was later damaged by fire in 1273 but granted land by Sumeimonin, the wife of the Emperor Gouda, in 1330 and was relocated slightly north of the former Rokujo site to a location west of Takakura-dori Street and south of Higuchikoji (present-day Manjuji-dori Street).
sen.cmt: 天皇表記"the" を追加しました。

sen.j: 付近には下京区万寿寺町、万寿寺中之町の町名が残る。
sen.e: The names of the nearby towns of Manjuji-cho and Manjuji Nakanocho in Simogyo Ward remain from this time.
The names of the nearby towns of Manjuji-cho and Manjuji Nakanocho in Simogyo Ward remain from this time.
The names of the nearby towns of Manjuji-cho and Manjuji Nakanocho in Simogyo Ward remain from this time.

sen.j: 室町時代には当初は十刹の第4位であったが、後に五山に昇格し、更に京都五山の第5位に数えられたが、永享6年（1434年）の火災後、衰微した。
sen.e: During the Kamakira period, Manju-ji Temple was ranked as the 4th of the 10 temples and later promoted to one of the Gozan (five temples) as well as the 5th of the Kyoto Gozan but fell into decline following a fire that broke out in 1434.

During the Kamakira period, Manju-ji Temple was ranked as the 4th of the 10 temples and later promoted to one of the Gozan (five temples) as well as the 5th of the Kyoto Gozan but fell into decline following a fire that broke out in 1434.

During the Kamakura period, Manju-ji Temple was ranked as the 4th of the 10 temples and later promoted to one of the Gozan (five temples) as well as the 5th of the Kyoto Gozan but fell into decline following a fire that broke out in 1434.

sen.j: 天正年間（1573－1592）には五山第4位の東福寺の北側にあった三聖寺の隣地に移転した。
sen.e: The temple was relocated to a site adjacent to Sansho-ji Temple to the north of Tofuku-ji Temple, the 4th of the Gozan, between 1573 and 1592.
The temple was relocated to a site adjacent to Sansho-ji Temple to the north of Tofuku-ji Temple, the 4th of the Gozan, between 1573 and 1592.
The temple was relocated to a site adjacent to Sansho-ji Temple to the north of Tofuku-ji Temple, the 4th of the Gozan, between 1573 and 1592.

sen.j: これは三聖寺の開山が万寿寺と同じ十地覚空と東山湛照であった縁によるものという。
sen.e: This relocation was due to the fact that the founding priest of Sansho-ji Temple was Jitchi Kakuku of Manju-ji Temple.
This relocation was due to the fact that the founding priest of Sansho-ji Temple was Jitchi Kakuku of Manju-ji Temple.
This relocation was due to the fact that the founding priest of Sansho-ji Temple was Jichi Kakuku and Tozan Tansho of Manju-ji Temple.

sen.j: 三聖寺は鎌倉時代には禅宗式の大伽藍を持つ有力寺院であったが次第に衰微し、明治6年（1873年）に万寿寺に合併された。
sen.e: During the Kamakura period, Sansho-ji Temple was a highly influential temple with a complex of Zen style buildings but it gradually fell into decline and merged with Manju-ji Temple in 1873.
During the Kamakura period, Sansho-ji Temple was a highly influential temple with a complex of Zen style buildings but it gradually fell into decline and merged with Manju-ji Temple in 1873.
During the Kamakura period, Sansho-ji Temple was a highly influential temple with a complex of Zen style buildings but it gradually fell into decline and merged with Manju-ji Temple in 1873.

sen.j: 明治19年（1886年）には万寿寺が東福寺の塔頭となり、21世紀に至っている。
sen.e: In 1886, Manju-ji Temple became and remains a sub-temple of Tofuku-ji Temple.
In 1886, Manju-ji Temple became and remains a sub-temple of Tofuku-ji Temple.
In 1886, Manju-ji Temple became and remains a sub-temple of Tofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 『東福寺誌』によると、明治14年（1881年）に東福寺の仏殿が焼失した際、万寿寺にあった釈迦三尊像を東福寺に移して新しい本尊とした。
sen.e: According to "Tofuku-ji shi", the Shaka triad statues of Manju-ji Temple were moved to Tofuku-ji Temple and installed as principal images after the butsuden (Buddha statue hall) of Tofuku-ji Temple was destroyed by fire in 1881.

According to "Tofuku-ji shi", the Shaka triad statues of Manju-ji Temple were moved to Tofuku-ji Temple and installed as principal images after the butsuden (Buddha statue hall) of Tofuku-ji Temple was destroyed by fire in 1881.

According to "Tofuku-ji shi," the Shaka triad statues of Manju-ji Temple were moved to Tofuku-ji Temple and installed as principal images after the butsuden (Buddha statue hall) of Tofuku-ji Temple was destroyed by fire in 1881.

sen.j: これが現在東福寺の本堂に安置される本尊釈迦三尊像で、元来は三聖寺に安置されていたものである。
sen.e: These Shaka triad statues that are currently housed within the Tofuku-ji Temple main hall were originally installed at Sansho-ji Temple.
These Shaka triad statues that are currently housed within the Tofuku-ji Temple main hall were originally installed at Sansho-ji Temple.
These Shaka triad statues that are currently housed within the Tofuku-ji Temple main hall were originally installed at Sansho-ji Temple.

sen.j: このほか、東福寺境内にある愛染堂と仁王門、万寿寺入口にある鐘楼（以上、各重要文化財）ももとは三聖寺の建物であった。
sen.e: In addition, the Aizen-do hall and Nio-mon gate within the Tofuku-ji Temple precinct, and the belfry at the entrance of Manju-ji Temple (all Important Cultural Properties) all originally belonged to Sansho-ji Temple.

In addition, the Aizen-do hall and Nio-mon gate within the Tofuku-ji Temple precinct, and the belfry at the entrance of Manju-ji Temple (all Important Cultural Properties) all originally belonged to Sansho-ji Temple.

In addition, the Aizen-do hall and Nio-mon gate within the Tofuku-ji Temple precinct, and the belfry at the entrance of Manju-ji Temple (all Important Cultural Properties) all originally belonged to Sansho-ji Temple.

sen.j: 昭和10年（1935年）には京都市電と東大路通、九条通の開通により境内が分断され、万寿寺は東福寺の飛び地のような位置に置かれることとなった。
sen.e: With the opening of the Kyoto municipal streetcar, Higashioji-dori Street and Kujo-dori Street in 1935, the temple precinct was divided and Manpuku-ji Temple became a detached part of the Tofuku-ji Precinct.

With the opening of the Kyoto municipal streetcar, Higashioji-dori Street and Kujo-dori Street in 1935, the temple precinct was divided and Manpuku-ji Temple became a detached part of the Tofuku-ji Precinct.

With the opening of the Kyoto municipal streetcar, Higashioji-dori Street and Kujo-dori Street in 1935, the temple precinct was divided and Manpuku-ji Temple became a detached part of the Tofuku-ji Precinct.

sen.j: 客殿（京都府指定文化財）
sen.e: Kyakuden (guest hall) (cultural property designated by Kyoto Prefecture)
Kyakuden (guest hall) (cultural property designated by Kyoto Prefecture)

sen.j: 鐘楼（重要文化財）－室町時代の建築。
sen.e: Belfry (Important Cultural Property): Constructed during the Muromachi period.
Belfry (Important Cultural Property): Constructed during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 境内入口にある。
sen.e: Stands at the entrance to the precinct.
Stands at the entrance to the precinct.

sen.j: 上層に鐘を吊り、下層は門を兼ねている。
sen.e: The bell hands in the upper level and the lower level serves as a gate.
The bell hands in the upper level and the lower level serves as a gate.
The bell hands in the upper level and the lower level serves as a gate.

sen.j: 元は三聖寺の建物で、現在は東福寺の所有となっており、重要文化財としての指定名称は「東福寺鐘楼」である。
sen.e: The building originally belonged to Sansho-ji Temple but now belongs to Tofuku-ji Temple and is designated an Important Cultural Property as "Tofukuji Shoro" (Tofuku-ji Temple belfry).
The building originally belonged to Sansho-ji Temple but now belongs to Tofuku-ji Temple and is designated an Important Cultural Property as "Tofukuji Shoro" (Tofuku-ji Temple belfry).

sen.j: 木造阿弥陀如来坐像－平安時代後期。
sen.e: Wooden seated statue of Amida Nyorai: Crafted during the latter part of the Heian period.

sen.j: 像高281.8cmの巨像。
sen.e: It is a large statue at 281.8cm tall.

sen.j: 明治時代から長らく京都国立博物館に寄託されていたが、現在は東福寺の光明宝殿（非公開）に安置。
sen.e: The statue had long been deposited at Kyoto National Museum since the Meiji era but it is now housed within the Komyo hoden (treasure hall) (not open to the public) at Tofuku-ji Temple.

sen.j: 京阪本線およびJR奈良線「東福寺駅」下車、徒歩
sen.e: Walk from "Tofukuji Station" on the Keihan Railway main line and JR Nara line.
